title: Glamp out at Warwick Castle
text:
Glamp out at Warwick Castle Glamp out at Warwick Castle AS THE giant American bald eagle swooped down over my head I instinctively ducked. PUBLISHED: 11:26, Sun, Jul 26, 2015 | UPDATED: 11:39, Sun, Jul 26, 2015 GETTY Mernie and her boys learn about the past, tuck into a banquet and spend the night in a medieval tent 
As it whooshed past a second time, I could feel the air move through my hair. 
I hadn’t expected to get quite so up close and personal with the enormous eagles, buzzards and condors that filled the sky. 
Archie, the eagle that had ruffled my hair, had a wingspan of 6ft, which seemed huge until we were introduced to Rosie, the Andean condor. 
“This is the world’s largest flying bird,” explained my seven-year-old son Harry as he stared at the sky. 
“I read about it in school. They are, like, 10 miles wide.” 
Harry might have overestimated slightly but when Rosie stretched out a full 10ft wingspan as she flew over our heads, it was a sight to behold. 
Getting right into the thick of things is very much the sort of experience you’ll have at Warwick Castle. 
Forget looking at dusty old artefacts, instead the attractions are a mixture of interactive exhibits, hilarious live shows and exciting historical re-enactments. 
New for 2015 is the Time Tower, which tells the castle’s bloody 1,100-year history. And all in just 20 minutes. 
One of the rooms is filled with portraits of the people who have lived in the castle over the years. 
Suddenly they come to life to tell their own stories, from time to time leaving their picture frame to move to another when they have a disagreement. 
It’s all a bit Harry Potter and lots of fun. NC LUXURY: Home for the night 
Whatever your age there’s plenty to do at the castle. 
While my youngest son James enjoyed the adventure playground and watching the majestic peacocks as they strutted around, Harry couldn’t wait to get his hands on a bow and arrow to try out archery before playing Splat The Rat in the Horrid Histories: Medieval Mayhem area. 
Perhaps the most dramatic event of the day was the launch of the trebuchet. 
This 60ft-tall wooden siege device (the biggest in the world) is essentially a giant catapult that would have hurled rocks, fire and even disease-ridden animal carcasses at the enemy. 
As visitors gathered the scene was set: the only way to stop the enemy at the gates was to flatten them with a massive boulder fired by the trebuchet. 
Sleeping in the castle itself, my boys were thrilled at the prospect of a night in the medieval glamping field: 35 white tents decorated with medieval flags and banners, a 10-minute walk from the castle. 
It was actually pretty luxurious, with four-poster beds, fur throws and even a chandelier. 
After a delicious all-you-can-eat medieval-style feast in the banqueting tent we headed down for the evening’s entertainment. 
The children learned a magic trick at jester school, wannabe knights were taught jousting and swordplay and a falconer showed off a beautiful Harris hawk which Harry, to his delight, was allowed to hold. 
He hasn’t stopped talking about it since. GETTING THERE 
Warwick Castle (0871 663 1676/ warwick-castle.com/glamping ) offers tents from £200 per night (sleeps four), B&B. 
Price includes castle tickets for two days. Warwick tourism: 01926 492212/ visitwarwick.co.uk . Related articles
